importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article update, indicating the most recent reporting on NFL Week 7 results, including records, comebacks, and quarterback performances.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe from the start of the 2025 NFL season to Week 7 reflects the ongoing trend of late-game comebacks and quarterback performance shifts, highlighting the volatility of team outcomes.

keyTakeAways: The NFL has seen a record number of lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation this season, emphasizing the unpredictability and high drama of modern football.

Bo Nix’s dramatic fourth-quarter comeback with the Denver Broncos, overturning a 19-point deficit, marks the first time in NFL history a team has overcome a 18+ point lead after three quarters and been shut out.

Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first Super Bowl-era player to achieve 90% completion, over 200 yards passing, and over 50 yards rushing in a single game.
Quarterbacks Justin Fields and Tua Tagovailoa were benched during the game due to poor performances, signaling growing pressure on offensive leadership in struggling teams.
The Green Bay Packers' defense, led by Micah Parsons, disrupted Arizona's final drive, contributing to a late comeback victory and reinforcing the impact of defensive dominance.

The Miami Dolphins and New York Jets, both 1-13 combined after Week 7, face significant organizational turmoil, with coaching decisions and quarterback changes reflecting instability in their programs.

namedEntities.name: Jacoby Brissett

summaryOfNewsArticle: Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season was defined by dramatic late-game comebacks, record-breaking performances, and high-profile quarterback changes. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team to survive a shut-out scenario after leading by 18+ points in the first three quarters. Quarterback Bo Nix delivered a standout performance, throwing for two touchdowns and rushing for two, culminating in a game-winning field goal. The Green Bay Packers also secured a win through a final-quarter surge and defensive dominance, highlighted by Micah Parsons' key disruption. On the offensive side, Drake Maye of the New England Patriots broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Titans, marking a new era for the team. Meanwhile, poor performances by Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields led to their benchings by the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets, respectively, signaling growing instability in two struggling franchises. The article underscores the volatility and unpredictability of the current NFL season, with record-breaking lead changes and evolving quarterback dynamics reshaping team futures.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
